descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: A recent proliferation of edited volumes, special journal issues, dissertations, and historical monographs in Atlantic history aim to show that the early modern Atlantic was overwhelmingly African, Iberian, and indigenous American. As the field is reoriented away from its conventional northern Atlantic focus, scholars studying Latin America, Africa, and Europe have been compelled to take note of the field's insights, contributions, and analytical frameworks. We will read some of the best examples of this turn in Atlantic history, an inherently comparative, transnational, transcultural, and oceanic approach to the past, with an eye toward prevailing trends, methodologies, and topics; major schools of study; and ongoing debates about chronology, scope, and concepts (empire, nation, subject, citizen, slavery, feudalism, capitalism, commodity, ecosystem, revolution). What is the current state of the field? In what ways is the recent scholarship most persuasive?

TENTATIVE READING LIST:
J.H. Elliott, Empires of the Atlantic World (2007)
Karen Ordahl Kupperman, The Atlantic in World History (2012)
Stuart Schwartz, All Will Be Saved: Religious Tolerance and Salvation in the Iberian Atlantic World (2009) John Thornton, A Cultural History of the Atlantic World, 1250-1820 (2012)
Jace Weaver, The Red Atlantic: American Indigenes and the Making of the Modern World, 1000-1927 (2014)
John McNeil, Mosquito Empires: Ecology and War in the Greater Caribbean, 1620-1914 (2010)
Wim Klooster, Revolutions in the Atlantic World: A Comparative History (2009)
